courses.subject: ASEI
courses.title: Field trip to GBA: Aerospace Sciences and Earth Informatics
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with site visits in the Greater Bay Area (GBA). Through the guided visits to institutions and private sector relevant to the field of aerospace science and Earth informatics, students are given opportunity to explore and understand the current practices and research frontier in the field. Students are required to participate in all activities including the tutorial discussions and group presentation, and to submit an individual report afterwards.
courses.course_syllabus: Through the guided visits to leading institutions and private sector organizations specializing in aerospace science and Earth informatics, students gain invaluable opportunities to explore and understand contemporary practices, cutting-edge research, and innovative technologies. These experiences allow students to engage with industry experts, observe real-world applications, and stay informed about the latest advancements and trends in these dynamic fields.

* Discussion with students: view and suggestions will be gathered from students.

courses.subject: ASEI
courses.title: Introduction to Aerospace Science and Earth Informatics
courses.description: This introductory-level course offers a comprehensive overview of the fundamental concepts and applications within the fields of aerospace sciences and Earth informatics. Students will explore the evolution of the solar system, delve into the intricacies of Earth's planetary environment, understand the basics of the tools and technologies used to explore the Earth and space, and gain insights into the multidisciplinary field of aerospace science and engineering. The course emphasizes the acquisition and analysis of data from space and other planets, highlighting its significance in understanding our universe and improving life on Earth.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

* Explain the processes involved in the formation and evolution of the solar system.
* Describe the key components and dynamics of Earth's environment and compare them to other planetary environments.
* Understand the basic tools and technologies used to explore space and Earth.
* Understand the basic principles of aerospace science and engineering.
* Apply data analysis techniques to interpret space and planetary data for various applications.
* Recognize the significance of aerospace technologies in addressing global challenges and advancing scientific knowledge.
courses.course_syllabus:
Solar System Evolution:

* Formation and development of the solar system
* Characteristics of planets, moons, asteroids, and comets
* The role of gravitational forces and cosmic events in shaping celestial bodies

Earth and Planetary Environment:

* Earth's atmosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere
* Comparative study of planetary environments within the solar system
* Impacts of space weather on planetary environments

Aerospace Science:

* Fundamental principles of flight and propulsion
* Overview of aerospace materials and structures
* Introduction to aerodynamics and fluid dynamics

Aerospace Engineering:

* Design and development of aircraft and spacecraft
* Systems engineering and integration in aerospace projects
* Emerging technologies and innovations in aerospace engineering

Applications of Space and Planetary Data:

* Remote sensing and satellite imagery
* Data analysis techniques for space and planetary exploration
* Practical applications in climate science, natural disaster monitoring, and environmental management

courses.title: Intermediate Topics in Aerospace Science and Earth Informatics
courses.description: The Intermediate Topics in Aerospace Science and Earth Informatics covers intermediate-level topics such as Aerodynamics through lectures and tutorials/project work. Exploration of the principles of aerodynamics, focusing on the fundamentals of fluid dynamics and airflow. Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of lift, drag, and other aerodynamic forces, as well as the tools to analyze airfoil and wing performance. The course is essential for anyone interested in the field of aerospace engineering, as it forms the basis for designing and optimizing aircraft and other aerospace vehicles.
courses.learning_outcomes:
​​By the end of this course, students will be able to:

* Understand and apply the fundamental principles of fluid dynamics to aerodynamic problems.
* Analyze and predict the behavior of lift and drag forces on different aerodynamic surfaces.
* Evaluate the performance of airfoils and wings using both theoretical and experimental methods.
* Utilize computational tools for aerodynamic analysis and design.
courses.course_syllabus:
Fundamentals of Fluid Dynamics and Airflow:

* Basic properties of fluids and gases
* Continuity equation, Bernoulli's principle, and conservation laws
* Flow types: laminar, turbulent, and transitional

Lift, Drag, and Aerodynamic Forces:

* Definition and significance of lift and drag forces
* Coefficients of lift and drag and their dependencies
* Analysis of boundary layers and separation

Analysis of Airfoil and Wing Performance:

* Airfoil geometry and characteristics
* Lift and drag coefficients of airfoils
* Wing planforms, aspect ratio, and lift distribution
* Vortex dynamics and downwash effects

courses.subject: ASEI
courses.title: Advanced Topics in Aerospace Science and Earth Informatics
courses.description: This course will cover advanced topics in Aerospace Science and Earth Informatics, such as orbital mechanics, whereby students will delve into the fundamental principles of classical mechanics with a focus on the motions of celestial bodies and artificial satellites under the influence of gravitational forces. Students will explore the mathematical and physical foundations of orbital dynamics, gaining the skills necessary to analyze and predict the trajectories of spacecraft and other objects in space. The course is essential for understanding space missions, satellite operations, and interplanetary travel.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

* Understand the fundamental principles of celestial mechanics and orbital dynamics.
* Analyze and predict the motions of satellites and other space objects.
* Plan and execute orbital maneuvers and transfers.
* Design and optimize space missions based on mission objectives and constraints.
courses.course_syllabus:
Principles of Celestial Mechanics:

* Newton's laws of motion and universal gravitation
* Kepler's laws of planetary motion
* Two-body problem and orbital elements

Orbital Dynamics:

* Types of orbits: circular, elliptical, parabolic, and hyperbolic
* Orbital maneuvers and transfers (Hohmann transfer, bi-elliptic transfer)
* Perturbations and their effects on orbits

Satellite Motion and Trajectory Analysis:

* Satellite launch and insertion into orbit
* Orbital decay and re-entry dynamics
* Rendezvous and docking procedures

Space Mission Planning and Design:

* Mission objectives and requirements
* Trajectory optimization and mission analysis
* Spacecraft design considerations for different mission types
